docs.snippet: Spelman’s highly unusual move to eliminate the athletic department comes at a time when few institutions seem to be able to resist the lure of intercollegiate sports....
docs.lead_paragraph: Spelman’s highly unusual move to eliminate the athletic department comes at a time when few institutions seem to be able to resist the lure of intercollegiate sports.
docs.abstract: Spelman College announces that it will shut down its athletics department, making it second institution in last decade to leave National Collegiate Athletic Assn altogether; move is prompted by both cost concerns and desire by school officials to divert sports funding toward establishing wellness program for students.

headline.seo: At Spelman, Dropping Sports in Favor of Fitness
headline.main: At a College, Dropping Sports in Favor of Fitness
headline.print_headline: At a College, Dropping Sports in Favor of Fitness

docs.snippet: SCHERR--Leslie, Age 74, formerly of Potomac, MD, died on April 4, 2013. Leslie was born in the Bronx, on April 17, 1938. He graduated from Queens College and received his Juris Doctor from Columbia Law School. Leslie was a first generation America...
docs.lead_paragraph: SCHERR--Leslie, Age 74, formerly of Potomac, MD, died on April 4, 2013. Leslie was born in the Bronx, on April 17, 1938. He graduated from Queens College and received his Juris Doctor from Columbia Law School. Leslie was a first generation American, self-made man, who had a lust for life and knowledge. He was an accomplished attorney who practiced criminal, civil and adoption law based in Washington, D.C. and litigated cases around the country. Leslie was an avid reader and accumulated an eclectic library. He volunteered at local libraries, raised money for charities and was a cooking instructor at L'Academie de Cuisine. He loved the New York Times, Jeopardy, all types of music, politics and debate, college basketball, travel, crossword puzzles, chess, bridge, scrabble, and above all his family and friends. He is survived by his wife, Susan Scherr; his son, Sloan Scherr and husband Patrick Moore; his daughter, Nikki O'Connell and husband Jim; his three grandchildren, Ryan, Aidan, and Madison; his sister Norma R. Ascher and husband Harvey; his uncle and aunt, Seymour and Thelma Grossman; aunt Geraldine Grossman; his sister-in-law Dr. Anita Auerbach; his nieces and nephews; his "daughters" Helen Taylor, Kristin Abshire, Charlotte Gilbert and Cathy Quinn; and the rest of his family and friends. A Celebration of Leslie's life will be held the first weekend of May, 2013 in Washington, D.C. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Queens College Foundation, c/o The Leslie Scherr Scholarship Fund, Attn: David D'Amato, 65-30 Kissena Blvd., Flushing, New York, 11367 or on-line at http://bit.ly/HonorLeslieScherr

docs.abstract: Dan Gilbert, Detroit native and fantastically wealthy founder and chairman of Quicken Loans, is investing heavily to revive two-square-mile downtown area of Detroit that was once its business core.

headline.main: A Missionary’s Quest to Remake Motor City
